div.p: A SERMON VPON THE EIGHTH VERSE OF THE FIRST CHAPTER OF THE ACTS OF THE APOSTLES.
Preached To the Honourable Company of the VIRGINIAN PLANTATION, 13. Nouemb. 1622.
BY IOHN DONNE Deane of Saint Pauls, LONDON.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Iones. 1624.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRABLE COMPANIE OF THE VIRGINIAN PLANTATION.
div.p:
BY your Fauours, I had ≈øome place amongst you, before; but now I am an Aduenturer, if not to VIRGINIA, yet for VIRGINIA: for, euery man that Prints, Aduentures. For the Preaching of this Sermon, I was but vnder your Inuitation; my Time was mine owne, and my Meditations mine owne: and I had beene excu≈øable towards you, if I had turned that Time, and tho≈øe Meditations, to GODS Seruice, in any other place. But for the Printing of this Sermon, I am not onely vnder your Inuitation, but vnder your
Commandement; for, after it was preached, it was not mine, but yours: And therefore, if I gaue it at fir≈øt, I doe but restore it now. The fir≈øt, was an act of Loue; this, of Iu≈øtice: both which Vertues, Almightie God euermore promoue, and exalt in all your proceedings. AMEN.

closer.signed: Your humble Seruant in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, IOHN DONNE.

epigraph.q: But yee ≈øhall receiue power after that the HOLY GHOST is come vpon you, and yee ≈øhall be witne≈ø≈øes vnto mee both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt part of the Earth.

div.p:
THERE are reckoned in this Booke, Two and Twentie Sermons of the Apo≈øtles; and yet the Book is not called the Preaching, but the Practi≈øe, not the Words, but the Acts of the Apo≈øtles: and the Acts of the Apo≈øtles were to conuey that name of Christ Ie≈øus, and to propagate
his Go≈øpell ouer all the world: Beloued, you are Actors vpon the ≈øame Stage too: the vttermo≈øt part of the Earth are your Scene: Act ouer the Acts of the Apo≈øtles; bee you a Light to the Gentiles, that ≈øit in darkene≈ø≈øe; bee you content to carrie him ouer the≈øe Seas, who dryed vp one Red Sea for his fir≈øt people, and hath powred out another Red Sea, his owne Bloud, for them and vs. When man was fallen, God cloathed him, made him a Leather Garment; there God de≈øcended to one Occupation: when the time of mans Redemption was come, then God, as it were, to hou≈øe him, became a Carpenters Sonne, there God de≈øcended to another Occupation. Naturally, without doubt, man would haue beene his owne Taylor, and his owne Carpenter; ≈øomething in the≈øe two kinds man would haue done of him≈øelfe, though hee had had no patterne from God: but
in pre≈øeruing man who was fallen, to this redemption, by which he was to be rai≈ød, in pre≈øeruing man from peri≈øhing, in the Flood, God de≈øcended to a third occupation, to be his Shipwright to giue him the modell of a Ship, an Arke, and ≈øo to be the author of that, which man him≈øelfe in likelihood, would neuer haue thought of, a means to pa≈ø≈øe from Nation to Nation. Now, as GOD taught vs to make cloathes, not onely to cloath our ≈øelues, but to cloath him in his poore and naked members heere; as God taught vs to build hou≈øes, not to hou≈øe our ≈øelues, but to hou≈øe him, in erecting Churches, to his glory: So God taught vs to make Ships, not to tran≈øport our ≈øelues, but to tran≈øport him, That when wee haue receiued power, after that the Holy Gho≈øt is come vpon vs, we might be witne≈ø≈øes vnto him, both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudaea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth.

As I ≈øpeake now principally to them who are concernd in this Plantation of Virginia, yet there may be diuers in this Congregation, who, though they haue no intere≈øt in this Plantation, yet they may haue benefit and edification, by that which they heare me ≈øay, ≈øo Chri≈øt ≈øpoke the words of this Text, principally to the Apo≈øtles, who were pre≈øent and que≈øtioned him at his A≈øcention, but they are in their iu≈øt extention, and due accomodation, appliable to our pre≈øent occation of meeting heere: As Chri≈øt him≈øelfe is Alpha, and Omega, ≈øo fir≈øt, as that hee is la≈øt too, ≈øo the≈øe wordes which he ≈øpoke in the Ea≈øt, belong to vs, who are to glorifie him in the We≈øt? That we hauing receiued power, after that the Holy Gho≈øt is come vpon vs, might be witne≈ø≈øes vnto him, both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth.

The fir≈øt word of the Text is the
Cardinall word, the word the hinge vpon which the whole Text turnes; The fir≈øt word, But, is the But, that all the re≈øt ≈øhoots at. Fir≈øt it is an exclu≈øiue word; ≈øomething the Apo≈øtles had required, which might not bee had; not that; And it is an inclu≈øiue word; ≈øomthing Chri≈øt was plea≈ød to affoord to the Apo≈øtles, which they thought not of; not that, not that which you beat vpon, But, but yet, ≈øomething el≈øe, ≈øomething better then that, you ≈øhall haue. That which this but, excludes, is that which the Apo≈øtles expre≈ø≈øe in the Ver≈øe immediatly before the Text, a Temporall Kingdome; Wilt thou re≈øtore againe the kingdome of I≈ørael? No; not a temporall Kingdome; let not the riches and commodities of this world, be in your contemplation in your aduentures. Or, becau≈øe they aske more, Wilt thou now re≈øtore that? not yet: If I will giue you riches, and commoditles of this world, yet if I doe it not at
fir≈øt, if I doe it not yet, be not you di≈øcouraged; you ≈øhall not haue that, that is not Gods fir≈øt intention; and though that be in Gods intention, to giue it you hereafter, you ≈øhall not haue it yet; thats the exclu≈øiue part; But; there enters the inclu≈øiue, You ≈øhall receiue power, after that the Holy Gho≈øt is come vpon you, and you ≈øhall bee witne≈ø≈øes vnto mee, both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudaea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth. In which ≈øecond part, we ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe by the≈øe ≈øteps; Superueniet Spiritus, The holy Gho≈øt ≈øhall come vpon you, The Spirit ≈øhall witne≈ø≈øe to your Spirit, and rectifie your Con≈øcience; And then, by that, you ≈øhall receiue power; A new power be≈øides the power you haue from the State, and that power ≈øhall enable you, to be witne≈ø≈øes of Chri≈øt, that is, to make his doctrine the more credible, by your te≈øtimony, when you conforme your ≈øelues to him, and doe as hee did; and this
witne≈ø≈øe you ≈øhall beare, this conformity you ≈øhall declare, fir≈øt in Ieru≈øalem, in this Citie; And in Iudaea, in all the parts of the Kingdome; and in Samaria, euen among≈øt them who are departed from the true wor≈øhip of God, the Papi≈øts; and to the vttermo≈øt part of the Earth, to tho≈øe poore Soules, to whom you are continually ≈øending. Summarily, If from the Holy Gho≈øt you haue a good te≈øtimony in your owne Con≈øcience, you ≈øhall be witne≈ø≈øes for Chri≈øt, that is, as he did, you ≈øhall giue ≈øatisfaction to all, to the Citie, to the Countrey, to the Calumniating Aduer≈øary, and the naturals of the place, to whom you ≈øhall pre≈øent both Spirituall and Temporall benefit to. And ≈øo you haue the Modell of the whole frame, and of the partitions; wee proceede now to the furni≈øhing of the particular roomes.

div.head: 1. Part.
div.p:
FIr≈øt then, this fir≈øt word, But, excludes a temporall Kingdome; the Apo≈øtles had fild them≈øelues with an expectation, with an ambition of it; but that was not intended them. It was no wonder, that a woman could conceiue ≈øuch an expectation, and ≈øuch an ambition, as to haue her two ≈øonnes ≈øit at Chri≈øts right hand, Mat. 20.20. and at his left, in his Kingdome, when the Apo≈øtles expected ≈øuch a Kingdome, as might affoord them honours and preferment vpon Earth. More then once they were in the di≈øputation, in which Chri≈øt deprehended them, Mat. 1.81. which of them ≈øhould bee the greate≈øt in his Kingdome. Neither hath the Bi≈øhop of Rome, any thing, wherein he may ≈øo properly call him≈øelfe Apo≈øt licall, as this error of the Apo≈øtles, this theire infirmitie; that heis euermore too conuer≈øant vpoÃÑ the contemplation
of temporall Kingdomes. They did it all the way, when Chri≈øt was with them, and now at his la≈øt ≈øtep, Cum actu a≈øcendi≈ø≈øet, when Chri≈øt was not A≈øending, but in part a≈øcended, when one foot was vpon the Earth, and the other in the cloud that tooke him vp, they aske him now, wilt thou at this time, re≈øtore the Kingdome? ≈øo women put their husbands, and men their fathers, and friends, vpon their torture, at their la≈øt ga≈øpe, and make their death- bed a racke to make them ≈øtrech and encrea≈øe ioyntures, and portions, and legacies, and ≈øigne Scedules and Codicils, with their hand, when his hand that pre≈øents them is ready to clo≈øe his eyes, that ≈øhould ≈øigne them: And when they are vpon the wing for heauen, men tye lead to their feet, and when they are laying hand fa≈øt vpon Abrahams bo≈øome, they mu≈øt pull their hand out of his bo≈øome againe, to obey importunities of men, and ≈øigne
their papers: ≈øo vnderminable is the loue of this World, which determines euery minute. GOD, as hee is three per≈øons, hath three Kingdomes; There is Regnum potentiae, The Kingdome of power; and this wee attribute to the Father; it is power and prouidence: There is Regnum gloriae, the Kingdome of glorie; this we attribute to the Sonn and to his purcha≈øe; for he is the King that ≈øhall ≈øay, Mat. 25.34. Come ye blo≈ø≈øed of my Father, inherit the Kingdome prepared for you, from the foundation of the World. And then betweene the≈øe three is Regnum Gratiae, The Kingdome of Grace, and this weattribute to the Holy Gho≈øt; he takes them, whom the king of power, Almighty God hath re≈øcued from the Gentiles, and as the king of grace, Hee giues them the knowledge of the mi≈øterie of the Kingdome of GOD, Mat. 4.11. that is, of future glory, by ≈øanctifying theÃÑ with his grace, in his Church. The two fir≈øt kingdomes are in this world, but
yet neither of them, are of this world; becau≈øe both they referre to the kingdome of glory. The kingdome of the Father, which is the prouidence of God, does but pre≈øerue vs; The kingdome of the Holy Gho≈øt which is the grace of God, does but prepare vs to the kingdome of the Sonne, which is the glory of GOD; and thats in heauen. And therfore, though to good men, this world be the way to that kingdome, yet this kingdome is not of this world, ≈øayes Chi≈øt him≈øelfe: Though the Apo≈øtles them≈øelues, Iohn 18.36. as good a Schoole as they were bred in, could neuer take out that le≈ø≈øon yet that le≈ø≈øon Chri≈øt giues, and repeates to all, you ≈øeeke a Temporall kingdome, But, ≈øayes the Text, ≈øtop there, A kingdome you mu≈øt not haue.

Beloued in him, who≈øe kingdome, and Go≈øpell you ≈øeeke to aduance, in this Plantation, our Lord and Sauiour Christ Ie≈øus, if you ≈øeeke to e≈øtabli≈øh a
temporall kingdome there, you are not rectified, if you ≈øeeke to bee kings in either acceptation of the word; To be a King ≈øignifies Libertie and indepency, and Supremacie, to bee vnder no man, and to be a King ≈øignifies Abundance, and Omni≈øufficiencie, to neede no man. If tho≈øe that gouerne there, would e≈øtabli≈øh ≈øuch a gouernment, as ≈øhould not depend vpon this, or if tho≈øe that goe thither, propo≈øe to them≈øelues an exemption from Lawes, to liue at their libertie, this is to be Kings, to deue≈øt Allegeance, to bee vnder no man: and if tho≈øe that aduenture thither, propo≈øe to them≈øelues pre≈øent benefit, and profit, a ≈øodaine way to bee rich, and an aboundance of all de≈øirable commodities from thence, this is to be ≈øufficient of them≈øelues, and to neede no man: and to bee vnder no man and to neede no man, are the two acceptations of being Kings. Whom liberty drawes to goe, or pre≈øent profit
drawes to aduenture, are not yet in the right way. O, if you could once bring a Catechi≈øme to bee as good ware among≈øt them as a Bugle, as a knife, as a hatchet: O, if you would bee as ready to hearken at the returne of a ≈øhip, how many Indians were conuerted to Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, as what trees, or druggs, or Dyes that Ship had brought, then you were in your right way, and not till then; Libertie and Abundance, are Characters of kingdomes, and a kingdome is excluded in the Text; The Apo≈øtles were not to looke for it, in their employment, nor you in this your Plantation.

At lea≈øt CHRIST expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelfe thus farre, in this an≈øwer, that if he would giue them a kingdome, Non adhue. hee would not giue it them yet. They aske him, Wilt thou at this time, re≈øtore the kingdome? and hee an≈øwers, It is not for you to know the times: what≈øoeuer God will doe, Man mu≈øt not
appoint him his time. The Apo≈øtles thought of a kingdome pre≈øently after Chri≈øts departure; the comming of the Holy Gho≈øt, who lead them into all truthes, ≈øoone deliuered them of that error. Other men in fauour of the Iewes, interpreting all the prophe≈øies, which are of a Spirituall Kingdome, the kingdome of the Go≈øpell, into which, the Iewes ≈øhall be admitted) in a literall ≈øen≈øe, haue thought that the Iewes ≈øhall haue, not onely a temporall kingdome in the ≈øame place, in Ieru≈øalem againe, but becau≈øe they finde that kingdome which is promi≈øed, (that is the kingdome of the Go≈øpell) to bee expre≈ø≈øed in large phra≈øes, and in an abundant manner, applying all that largene≈ø≈øe to a temporall kingdome, they thinke, that the Iewes ≈øhall haue ≈øuch a kingdome, as ≈øhall ≈øwallow and annihilate all other kingdomes, and bee the ≈øole Empire and Monarchy of the world. After this, very great men in the Church
vpon the≈øe words, of One thou≈øand yeares after the Re≈øurrection, haue immagin'd a Temporall Kingdome of the Saints of God heere vpon Earth, Apo. 20. before they entred the ioyes of Heauen: and Saint Augu≈øtine him≈øelfe,
De Ciuit. Dei 20.7. had at fir≈øt ≈øome declinations towards that opinion, though he di≈øpute powerfully again≈øt it, after: That there ≈øhould bee Sabati≈ømus in terris; that as the world was to la≈øt Sixe thou≈øand yeares in troubles, there ≈øhould be a Seuenth thou≈øand, in ≈øuch ioyes as this world could giue.

And ≈øome others, who haue auoided both the Temporall kingdome imagin'd by the Apostles, pre≈øently after the A≈øcention, And the Emperiall kingdome of the Iewes, before the Re≈øurrection, And the Carnall kingdome of the Chiliasts, the Millenarians, after the Re≈øurrection, though they ≈øpeake of no kingdome, but the true kingdome, the kingdome of glory, yet they erre as
much in a≈øsigning a certaine time when that kingdome ≈øhall beginne, when the ende of this world, when the Re≈øurrection, when the Iudgement ≈øhall be. Non e≈øt vestrum no≈ø≈øe tempora, ≈øayes Chri≈øt to his Apo≈øtles then; and le≈øt it might be thought, that they might know the≈øe things, when the Holy Gho≈øt came vpon them, Chri≈øt denies that he him≈øelfe knew that, as Man; and as Man, Chri≈øt knew more, then euer the Apo≈øtles knew. What≈øoeuer therefore Chri≈øt intended to his Apo≈øtles heere, hee would not giue it pre≈øently, non adhuc, hee would not binde him≈øelfe to a certaine time, Non e≈øt ve≈øtrum no≈ø≈øe tempora, It belongs not to vs to know Gods times.

Beloued, v≈øe godly means, and giue God his lei≈øure. You cannot beget a Sonne, and tell the Mother, I will haue this Sonne born within fiue Moneths; nor, when he is borne, ≈øay, you will haue him pa≈øt daunger of Ward≈øhip
within fiue yeares. You cannot ≈øowe your Corne to day, and ≈øay it ≈øhall bee aboue ground to morrow, and in my Barne next weeke. How ≈øoone the be≈øt Husbandman, ≈øow'd the be≈øt Seede in the be≈øt ground? GOD ca≈øt the promi≈øe of a Me≈øsias, as the ≈øeede of all, in Paradi≈øe; In Semine Mulieris; The Seede of the Woman ≈øhall brui≈øe the Serpents head; and yet this Plant was Foure thou≈øand yeares after before it appeared; this Me≈øsias Foure thou≈øand yeares before he came. GOD ≈øhew'd the ground where that ≈øhould grow, Two thou≈øand yeares after the Promi≈øe; in Abrahams Family; In ≈øemine tuo, In thy Seed all Nations ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed. God hedg'd in this Ground almo≈øt One thou≈øand yeares after that; In Micheas time, Et tu Bethlem, Thou Bethlem ≈øhalt bee the place; and God watered that, and weeded that, refre≈øhed that dry expectation, with a Succe≈ø≈øion of Prophets; and
yet it was ≈øo long before this expectation of Nations, this Me≈øsias came. So GOD promi≈øed the Iewes a Kingdome, in Iacobs Prophecie to Iuda, Gen. 49. That the Scepter ≈øhould not depart from his Tribe. In Two hundred yeares more, he ≈øaies no more of it; Deut. 17.14. then he ordaines ≈øome in≈øtitutions for their King, when they ≈øhould haue one. And then it was Foure hundred yeares after that, before they had a King. GOD meant from the fir≈øt houre, to people the whole earth; and God could haue made men of clay, as fa≈øt as they made Brickes of Clay in Egypt; but he began vpon two, and when they had beene multiplying and repleni≈øhing the Earth One thou≈øand ≈øixe hundred yeares, the Flood wa≈øhed all that away, and GOD was almo≈øt to begin againe vpon eight per≈øons; and they haue ≈øeru'd to people Earth and Heauen too; Bee not you di≈øcouraged, if the Promi≈øes which you haue made to your ≈øelues,
or to others, be not ≈øo ≈øoone di≈øcharg'd; though you ≈øee not your money, though you ≈øee not your men, though a Flood, a Flood of Bloud haue broken in vpon them, be not di≈øcouraged. Great Creatures lye long in the Wombe; Lyons are litterd perfit, but Beare-whelpes lick'd vnto their ≈øhape; actions which Kings vndertake, are ca≈øt in a mould, they haue their perfection quickly; actions of priuate men; and priuate Pur≈øes, require more hammering, and more filing to their perfection. Onely let your principall end, be the propagation of the glorious Go≈øpell: and though there bee an Exclu≈øiue in the Text, GOD does not promi≈øe you a Kingdome, Ea≈øe, and Abundance in all things, and that which hee does intend to you, he does not promi≈øe pre≈øently, yet there is an Inclu≈øiue too; not that, But, but ≈øomething equiuolent at lea≈øt, But yee ≈øhall receiue power, after that the Holy Gho≈øt is come vpon you, and yee ≈øhall
be witne≈ø≈øes vnto me, both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudaea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth.

div.head: 2. Part.
div.p:
Thus then this Text proceedes, Spiritus Sanctus. and gathers vpon you. All that you would haue by this Plantation, you ≈øhall not haue: GOD bindes not him≈øelfe to mea≈øures; All that you ≈øhall haue, you haue not yet: GOD bindes not him≈øelfe to times, but ≈øomething you ≈øhall haue; nay, you haue alreadie ≈øome great things: and of tho≈øe, that in the Text is, The Holy Gho≈øt ≈øhall come vpon you. Wee finde the Holy Gho≈øt to haue come vpon men, foure times in this Booke: Fir≈øt, vpon the Apo≈øtles, Acts 2, 1. at Pentecost: Then, when the whole Congregation was in prayer for the impri≈øonment of Peter and Iohn. 4, 31. Againe, when Peter preached in Cornelius his hou≈øe, 10, 44. the Holy Gho≈øt fell vpon all them that heard him. And fourthly, when Saint Paul laid his hands vpon them, 19, 6. who had beene formerly baptized at Ephe≈øus. At the three latter times it is euident, that the Holy Gho≈øt fell vpon whole and promi≈øcuous
Congregations, and not vpon the Apo≈øtles onely: and in the fir≈øt, at Penteco≈øt, the contrarie is not euident; nay, the Fathers, for the mo≈øt part, that handle that, concurre in that, that the Holy Gho≈øt fell then vpon the whole Congregation, men and women. The Holy Gho≈øt fell vpon Peter before hee preach'd, and it fell vpon the hearers when hee preach'd, and it hath fallen vpon euery one of them, who haue found motions in them≈øelues, to propagate the Go≈øpell of Christ Ie≈øus by this meanes. The Sonne of GOD did not abhorre the Virgins Wombe, when hee would be made man; when hee was man, hee did not di≈ødaine to ride vpon an A≈ø≈øe into Ieru≈øalem: the third Per≈øon of the Trinitie, the Holy Gho≈øt, is as humble as the ≈øecond, hee refu≈øes Nullum vehiculum, no conueyance, no doore of entrance into you; whether the example and precedent of other good men, or a probable imagination of future
profit, or a willingne≈ø≈øe to concurre to the vexation of the Enemie; what collaterall re≈øpect ≈øoeuer drew thee in, if now thou art in, thy principall re≈øpect be the glorie of God; that occa≈øion, what≈øoeuer it was, was vehiculum Spiritus Sancti; that was the Petard, that broke open thy Iron Gate; that was the Chariot, by which he entred into thee, and now hee is fallen vpon thee, if thou doe not Depo≈øe; (lay a≈øide all con≈øideration of profit for euer, neuer to looke for returne) No, not Sepo≈øe, (leaue out the con≈øideration of profit for a time; for that, and Religion may well con≈øi≈øt together:) but if thou doe but Po≈øt-po≈øe the con≈øideration of Temporall gayne, and ≈øtudie fir≈øt the aduancement of the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, the Holy Ghost is fallen vpon you; for by that you receiue Power, ≈øayes the Text.

Infamie is one of the highe≈øt puni≈øhments that the Law inflicts vpon man; Te≈øtes.
for it lyes vpon him euen after death: Infamie is the wor≈øt puni≈øhment, and Inte≈øtabilitie (to be made intestable) is one of the deepe≈øt wounds of Infamie; and then the wor≈øt degree of intestabilitie, is not to be beleeued, not to be admitted to be a Witne≈ø≈øe of any other: Hee is Inte≈øtable, that cannot make a Testament, not giue his owne goods; and hee Inte≈øtable, that can receiue nothing by the Te≈øtament of another; hee is Inte≈øtable, in who≈øe behalfe no te≈øtimonie may be accepted: but be is the mo≈øt mi≈øerably Intestable of all, the mo≈øt dete≈øtably inte≈øtable, that di≈øcredites another man, by ≈øpeaking well of him; and makes him the more ≈øu≈øpitious, by his commendations. A Chri≈øtian in profe≈ø≈øion, that is not a Chri≈øtian in life, is ≈øo inte≈øtable, hee di≈øcredites Chri≈øt, and hardens others again≈øt him. Iohn Bapti≈øt was more then a Prophet, becau≈øe hee was a Witne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt; and hee was a Witne≈ø≈øe,
becau≈øe hee was like him, hee did as hee did, hee lead a holy and a religious life; ≈øo hee was a Witne≈ø≈øe. That great and glorious name of Martyr, is but a Witne≈ø≈øe. Saint Stephen was Proto-martyr, Chri≈øts fir≈øt Witne≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe hee was the fir≈øt that did as hee did, that put on his Colours, that drunke of his Cup, that was bapti≈øed with his Bapti≈øme; with his owne Bloud: ≈øo hee was a Witne≈ø≈øe. To be Witne≈ø≈øes for Chri≈øt, is to be like Chri≈øt; to conforme your ≈øelues to Chri≈øt: and they in the Text, and you, are to be Witne≈ø≈øes of Chri≈øt in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudaea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth.

Saint Hierome notes, that Iohn Bapti≈øt was not bid to beare witne≈ø≈øe in Ieru≈øalem, Jeru≈øalem. in the Citie, but in the Wilderne≈ø≈øe; hee, and none but hee: there were but few men to witne≈ø≈øe to, there; and tho≈øe few that were, came thither with a good di≈øpo≈øition, to be wrought vpon there: and there, there were few
Witne≈ø≈øes to oppo≈øe Iohns Te≈øtimonie, few Tentations, few worldly Allurements, few worldly Bu≈øine≈ø≈øes. One was enough for the Wilderne≈ø≈øe; but for Ieru≈øalem, for the Citie, where all the excu≈øes in the Go≈øpell doe alwayes meete, they haue bought Commodities, and they mu≈øt vtter them; they haue ducha≈øed Lands, and they mu≈øt ≈øtate them, they haue married Wiues, and they mu≈øt ≈øtudie them: to the Citie, to Ieru≈øalem, Chri≈øt ≈øends all his Apo≈øtles, and all little enough. Hee hath ≈øent a great many Apo≈øtles, Preachers, to this Citie; more then to any other, that I know Religious per≈øons, as they call them, Cloi≈øtered Friars, are not ≈øent to the Citie; by their fir≈øt Canons, they ≈øhould not preach abroad: but for tho≈øe who are to doe that ≈øeruice, there are more in this Citie, then in others; for there are more Pari≈øh Churches heere, then in others. Now, beloued, if in this Citie you haue taken away a great part
of the reuenue of the Preacher, to your ≈øelues, take thus much of his labour vpon your ≈øelues too, as to preach to one another by a holy and exemplar life, and a religious conuer≈øation. Let tho≈øe of the Citie, who haue intere≈øt in the Gouernment of this Plantation, be Witne≈ø≈øes of Chri≈øt, who is Truth it ≈øelfe, to all other Gouernours of Companies, in all true and iu≈øt proceedings: That as CHRIST ≈øaid to them who thought them≈øelues greate≈øt, Except you become as this little Child; ≈øo wee may ≈øay to the Gouernours of the greate≈øt Companies, Except you proceed with the integrity, with the iu≈øtice, with the clearene≈ø≈øe of your little Si≈øter, this Plantation, you doe not take, you doe not follow a good example. This is to beare witne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt in Ieru≈øalem, in the Citie, to bee examples of Truth, and Iu≈øtice, and Clearene≈ø≈øe, to others, in, and of this Citie.

The Apo≈øtles were to doe this in Iudaea Iudaea.
too, their ≈øeruice lay in the Countrey as well as in the Citie. Birds that are kept in Cages, may learne ≈øome Notes, which they ≈øhould neuer haue ≈øung in the Woods, or Fields; but yet they may forget their naturall Notes too. Preachers that binde them≈øelues alwayes to Cities, and Courts, and great Auditories, may learne new Notes; they may become occa≈øionall Preachers, and make the emergent affaires of the time, their Text, and the humors of the hearers, their Bible: but they may lo≈øe their Naturall Notes, both the ≈øimplicitie and the boldne≈ø≈øe that belongs to the Preaching of the Go≈øpel; both their power vpon lowe Vnder≈øtandings, to ray≈øe them, and vpon high Affections, to humble them. They may thinke, that their Errand is but to knocke at the doore, to delight the eare, and not to ≈øearch the Hou≈øe, to ran≈øacke the Con≈øcience. Chri≈øt left the Ninetie and nine for one Sheepe; populous Cities are for the
mo≈øt part, be≈øt prouided; remoter parts need our labour more, and wee ≈øhould not make ≈øuch differences. Yeoman, and Labourer, and Spin≈øter, are di≈øtinctions vpon Earth, in the Earth; in the Graue there is no di≈øtinction. The Angell that ≈øhall call vs out of that Du≈øt, will not ≈øtand to ≈øuruay, who lyes naked, who in a Coffin, who in Wood, who in Lead; who in a fine, who in a cour≈øer Sheet: In that one day of the Re≈øurrection, there is not a fore-noone for Lords to ri≈øe fir≈øt, and an after-noone for meaner per≈øons to ri≈øe after. Chri≈øt was not whipp'd, to ≈øaue Beggars; and crown'd with Thornes, to ≈øaue Kings; hee dyed, hee ≈øuffered all, for all: and wee (who≈øe bearing witne≈ø≈øe of him, is to doe as hee did) mu≈øt conferre our Labours vpon all; vpon Ieru≈øalem, and vpon Iudaea too; vpon the Citie, and vpon the Countrey too. You (who are his Witne≈ø≈øes too) mu≈øt doe ≈øo too; Preach in your iu≈øt actions, as to the
Citie, to the Countrey too. Not to ≈øeale vp the ≈øecrets, and the my≈øteries of your bu≈øine≈ø≈øe within the bo≈øome of Merchants, and exclude all others: to nouri≈øh an incompatibilitie betweene Merchants & Gentlemen; that Merchants ≈øhall ≈øay to them in reproach, You haue playd the Gentlemen; and they in equall reproach, You haue playd the Merchant: but as Merchants grow vp into wor≈øhipfull Families, and wor≈øhipfull Families let fall Branches among≈øt Merchants againe; ≈øo for this particular Plantation, you may con≈øider Citie and Countrey to be one Body: and as you giue example of a iu≈øt Gouernment to other Companies in the Citie, (that's your bearing witne≈ø≈øe in Ieru≈øalem;) ≈øo you may be content to giue Rea≈øons of your Proceedings, and Account of Moneyes leuied ouer the Countrey, for that's your bearing witne≈ø≈øe in Iudaea.

But the Apo≈øtles Dioces is enlarged, farther then Ieru≈øalem, farther then Iudaea, Samaria. they are carried into Samaria; you must beare witne≈ø≈øe of me in Samaria. Beloued, when I haue remembred you, who the Samaritans were, Men that had not renounced GOD, but mingled other gods with him, Men that had not burned the Law of GOD, but made Traditions of Men equall to it; you will ea≈øily gue≈ø≈øe to whom I apply the name of Samaritans now. A Ie≈øuit hath told vs (an ill Intelligencer I confe≈ø≈øe, but euen his Intelligencer, the Deuill him≈øelfe, ≈øayes true ≈øometimes) Maldonate ≈øayes, the Samaritans were odious to the Iewes, vpon the ≈øame grounds as Heretiques and Schi≈ømatiques to vs; and they we know were odious to them, for mingling fal≈øe gods, and fal≈øe wor≈øhips with the true. And if that be the Caracter of a Samaritan, wee know who are the Samaritans, who the Heretiques, who the Schi≈ømatiques of our
times. In the highe≈øt reproach to Chri≈øt, the Iewes ≈øaid, Samaritanus es & Daemonium habes, Thou art a Samaritan, and ha≈øt a Deuill. In our iu≈øt dete≈øtation of the≈øe Men, we iu≈øtly fa≈øten both tho≈øe vpon them. For as they delight in lyes, and fill the world with weekely rumors, DaemoniuÃÑ habeÃÑt, they haue a Deuill, quia mendax e≈øt & pater eius. Iohn 8.44. As they multiply a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinats vpon Princes, and Ma≈ø≈øacres vpon people, Daemonium habent, they haue a Deuill, quia homicida ab initio: as they to≈ø≈øe, and tumble, and di≈øpo≈øe kingdomes, Daemonium habent, they haue a Deuill, Math. 4.10. Omnia haec dabo was the Deuils complement: but as they mingle truthes and fal≈øhoods together in Religion, as they carry the word of GOD, and the Traditions of Men, in an euen balance, Samaritani ≈øunt, they are Samaritanes. At fir≈øt Christ forbad his Apo≈øtles, to goe into any Citie of the Samaritans; after, 10.5. they did preach in many of them. Beare witne≈ø≈øe fir≈øt in
Ieru≈øalem, Acts 8.25. and in Iudaea; giue good ≈øatisfaction e≈øpecially to tho≈øe of the hou≈øehold of the Faithfull, in the Citie and Countrey, but yet ≈øatisfie euen tho≈øe Samaritans too.

They would be ≈øatisfied, what Miracles you work in Virginia, and what people you haue conuerted to the Chri≈øtian Faith, there. If wee could as ea≈øily call natural effects Miracles, or ca≈øuall accideÃÑts Miracles, or Magicall illu≈øions Miracles, as they do; to make a miraculous drawing of a Tooth, a miraculous cutting of a Corne; or, as Iu≈øtus Baronius ≈øayes, when he was conuerted to them, that he was miraculou≈øly cur'd of the Cholique, by ≈øtooping to ki≈ø≈øe the Popes foot: If wee would pile vp Miracles ≈øo fa≈øt as Pope Iohn 22. did in the Canonization of Aquinas, Tot Miracula confecit, quot determinauit quae≈øtiones, hee wrought as many Miracles, as he re≈øolu'd Que≈øtions, wee might find Miracles too. In truth, their greate≈øt Miracle to me, is,
that they find men to beleeue their Miracles. If they rely vpon Miracles, they imply a coÃÑfe≈ø≈øion, that they induce new Doctrines; that that is old, & receiu'd, needs no Miracles: If they require Miracles, becau≈øe though that be ancient Doctrine, it is newly brought into tho≈øe parts, wee haue the confe≈ø≈øion of their Ie≈øuit Aco≈øta, that they doe no Miracle in tho≈øe Indies; & he a≈ø≈øignes very good rea≈øons, why they are not nece≈ø≈øary, nor to be expected there. But yet beare witne≈ø≈øe to the≈øe Samaritans, in the other point; labour to giue them ≈øatisfaction in the other point of their charge, What Heathens you haue conuerted to the Faith; which is that which is intended in the next, which is the la≈øt branch, You are to be witne≈ø≈øes vnto me both in Ieru≈øalem, and in all Iudaea, and in Samaria, and vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the Earth.

Literally, Fines terrae. the Apo≈øtles were to be ≈øuch Witne≈ø≈øes for Chri≈øt: were they ≈øo? did the Apo≈øtles in per≈øon preach the Go≈øpel
ouer all the World? I know that it is not hard to multiply places of the Fathers, in confirmation of that opinion, that the Apo≈øtles did actually and per≈øonally preach the Go≈øpell in all Nations, Math. 24.14. in their life. Chri≈øt ≈øaies, The Go≈øpell of the Kingdome ≈øhall be preached in all the World; and there he tels the Apo≈øtles, that they ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øomething done, after that; Therefore they ≈øhall liue to it. So hee ≈øaies to them, Marke 13.9. You ≈øhall be brought before Rulers and Kings for my ≈øake; but the Go≈øpell mu≈øt fir≈øt be publi≈øhed among all Nations: In one Euangeli≈øt there is the Commi≈øsion; Luke 24.47. Preach in my name to all Nations. And in another, the Execution of this Commi≈øsion, Marke 16.20. And they went and preached euery where. And after the Apo≈øtle certifies, and returnes the execution of this Commi≈ø≈øion, Col. 1.5. The Go≈øpell is come and bringeth forth fruit to all the world: and vpon tho≈øe, and ≈øuch places, haue ≈øome of the Fathers beene plea≈øed to ground their literall expo≈øition, of an actuall
and per≈øonall preaching of the Apo≈øtles ouer all the world. But had they dream'd of this world which hath beene di≈øcouer'd ≈øince, into which, we di≈øpute with perplexitie, and intricacy enough, how any men came at fir≈øt, or how any bea≈øts, e≈øpecially ≈øuch bea≈øts as men were not likely to carry, they would neuer haue doubted to haue admitted a Figure, in that, Luke 1.1. The Go≈øpell was preached to all the world; for when Augu≈øtus his Decree went out, That all the World ≈øhould bee taxed, the Decree and the Taxe went not certainly into the West Indies; when Saint Paul ≈øayes, Rom 1.8.16.19. That their Faith was ≈øpoken of throughout the whole World, and that their obedience was come abroad vnto all men, ≈øurely the We≈øt Indies had not heard of the faith and the obedience of the Romanes. But as in Mo≈øes time, they called the Mediterranean Sea, the great Sea, becau≈øe it was the greate≈øt that tho≈øe men had then ≈øeene, ≈øo in the
Apo≈øtles time, they call'd that all the World, which was knowne and traded in then; and in all that, they preach'd the Go≈øpell. So that as Chri≈øt when hee ≈øaid to the Apo≈øtles; Mar. vlt. vlt. I am with you vnto the end of the World, could not intend that of them in per≈øon, becau≈øe they did not la≈øt to the end of the World, but in a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Apo≈øtolike men, ≈øo when he ≈øayes, the Apo≈øtles ≈øhould preach him to all the World, it is of the Succe≈øsion too.

Tho≈øe of our profe≈ø≈øion, that goe; you, that ≈øend them who goe, doe all an Apo≈øtolicall Function. What Action ≈øoeuer hath in the fir≈øt intention thereof a purpo≈øe to propagate the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, that is an Apo≈øtolicall Action: Before the end of the World come, before this Mortalitie ≈øhall put on Immortalitie, Rom. 8. before the Creature ≈øhall be deliuered of the Bondage of Corruption vnder which it groanes, before the Martyrs vnder the Altar
≈øhall be ≈øilenc'd, before all things ≈øhall be ≈øubdued to Chri≈øt, his Kingdome perfited, and the la≈øt Enemie (Death) de≈øtroyed, the Go≈øpell mu≈øt be preached to tho≈øe men to whom ye ≈øend, to all men. Further and ha≈øten you this ble≈ø≈øed, this ioyfull, this glorious con≈øummation of all, and happie re-vnion of all Bodies to their Soules, by preaching the Go≈øpell to tho≈øe men. Preach to them Doctrinally, preach to them Practically; enamore them with your Iu≈øtice, and (as farre as may con≈øi≈øt with your ≈øecuritie) your Ciuilitie; but inflame them with your Godline≈ø≈øe, and your Religion. Bring them to loue and reuerence the name of that King, that ≈øends men to teach them the wayes of Ciuilitie in this World, but to feare and adore the Name of that King of Kings, that ≈øends men to teach them the wayes of Religion, for the next World. Tho≈øe amoÃÑg≈øt you, that are old now, ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe out of this World with this great comfort,
that you contributed to the beginning of that Common Wealth, and of that Church, though they liue not to ≈øee the growth thereof to perfection: Apollo watred, 1. Cor. 3.6. but Paul planted; he that begun the worke, was the greater man. And you that are young now, may liue to ≈øee the Enemy as much impeached by that place, and your friends, yea Children, a≈øwell accommodated in that place, as any other. You ≈øhall haue made this Iland, which is but as the Suburbs of the old world, a Bridge, a Gallery to the new; to ioyne all to that world that ≈øhall neuer grow old, the Kingdome of Heauen, You ≈øhall adde per≈øons to this Kingdome, and to the Kingdome of Heauen, and adde names to the Bookes of our Chronicles, and to the Booke of Life.

To end all, as the Orators which declaimed in the pre≈øence of the Roman Emperors, in their Panegyriques, tooke that way, to make tho≈øe Emperours ≈øee
what they were bound to doe, to ≈øay in tho≈øe publique Orations, that tho≈øe Emperors had done ≈øo, (for that increa≈øed the loue of the Subiect to the Prince, to be ≈øo told, that he had done tho≈øe great things, and then it conuayd a Coun≈øell into the Prince to doe them after.) As their way was to procure things to be done, by ≈øaying they were done, ≈øo beloued I haue taken a contrary way: for when I, by way of exhortation, all this while haue ≈øeemed to tell you what ≈øhould be done by you; I haue, indeed, but told the Congregation, what hath beene done already: neither doe I ≈øpeake to moue a wheele that ≈øtood ≈øtill, but to keepe the wheele in due motion; nor per≈øwade you to begin, but to continue a good worke; nor propo≈øe forreigne, but your owne Examples, to doe ≈øtill, as you haue done hitherto. For, for that, that which is e≈øpecially in my contemplation, the conuer≈øion of the
people, as I haue receiu'd, ≈øo I can giue this Te≈øtimonie, That of tho≈øe per≈øons who haue ≈øent in Moneyes, and conceal'd their Names, the greate≈øt part, almo≈øt all, haue limitted their Deuotion and Contribution vpon that point, the propagation of Religion, and the conuer≈øion of the People; for the building and beautifying of the Hou≈øe of GOD, and for the in≈øtruction and education of their young Children. Chri≈øt Ie≈øus him≈øelfe is ye≈øterday, and to day, and the ≈øame for euer. In the aduancing of his Glory, be you ≈øo too, ye≈øterday, and to day, and the ≈øame for euer, here: and hereafter, when Time ≈øhall be no more, no more ye≈øterday, no more to day, yet for euer and euer you ≈øhall enioy that ioy, and that glorie, which no ill accident can attayne to dimini≈øh, or Eclip≈øe it.

div.head: PRAYER.
div.p:
WE returne to thee againe, O GOD, with Pray≈øe and Prayer; as for all thy mercies from before Minutes began, to this Minute; from our Election, to this pre≈øent Beame of Sanctification, which thou ha≈øt ≈øhed vpon vs now: and more particularly, that thou ha≈øt afforded vs that great Dignitie, to be this way Witne≈ø≈øes of thy Sonne Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, and In≈øtruments of his Glorie. Looke graciou≈øly, and looke powerfully vpon this Body, which thou ha≈øt been now ≈øome yeeres in building and compacting together, this Plantation. Looke graciou≈øly vpon the Head of this Body, our Soueraigne, and ble≈ø≈øe him with a good di≈øpo≈øition to this Worke, and ble≈ø≈øe him for that di≈øpo≈øition: Looke graciou≈øly vpon them, who are as the Braine of this Body, tho≈øe who by his power
coun≈øaile, and adui≈øe, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the Gouernment thereof: ble≈ø≈øe them with di≈øpo≈øition to Vnitie and Concord, and ble≈ø≈øe them for that di≈øpo≈øition.
